article: Mackenzie Hughes had just returned from school and was waiting for her older brothers to arrive home. She was home alone _ a man started knocking on the front door, turning the handle and trying to get in . She's 12 years old and she was _ . So she dialed 9-1-1 and reached the operator Rachelle Berry. After a brief talk, Berry _ what was happening. "OK, hang on, OK? Can you get in a _ ?" Berry asked. Mackenzie told Berry that her phone --- it wasn't cordless --- wouldn't reach into the cupboard. "Will the phone reach under your bed?" Berry asked _ . "No," Mackenzie said. "Can you hide under a _ and pull your bedspread over you?" That's _ what Mackenzie did. She hid under her blanket, holding the phone and listening to Berry's voice. Berry talked quietly, which _ Mackenzie. It helped, too, when Berry told her to think of something _ . "Try not to cry," Berry told Mackenzie during the call. " I know it's _ . Do you have something you can hold onto?" Mackenzie struggled to hold back tears. She couldn't _ anything without showing her hiding spot. " It's OK," Berry said. "You've got me here with you." "He's in my room," Mackenzie _ . "Now be quiet, OK? Just don't talk," Berry said. For much of the call, Berry dropped her voice to a whisper, _ the might hear her voice over the phone. _ , the man came into her room, then left. Berry told Mackenzie that the _ were on their way. Minutes later, they arrived and _ one man in the backyard and another man in a getaway car. On Thursday morning, the Emergency Communications Bureau gave Mackenzie its Hero Award for her _ . Berry also received high praise. And then it was off to school for Mackenzie. But first Berry had something to _ to the middle-schooler: a cordless phone.
